title: ICCV_2001_47_abs

sentences.text: We propose to incorporate a priori geometric constraints in a 3 -- D stereo reconstruction scheme to cope with the many cases where image information alone is not sufficient to accurately recover 3 -- D shape .
Our approach is based on the iterative deformation of a 3 -- D surface mesh to minimize an objective function .
We show that combining anisotropic meshing with a non-quadratic approach to regularization enables us to obtain satisfactory reconstruction results using triangulations with few vertices .
Structural or numerical constraints can then be added locally to the reconstruction process through a constrained optimization scheme .
They improve the reconstruction results and enforce their consistency with a priori knowledge about object shape .
The strong description and modeling properties of differential features make them useful tools that can be efficiently used as constraints for 3 -- D reconstruction .

summary: We propose to incorporate a priori geometric constraints in a 3 -- D stereo reconstruction scheme to cope with the many cases where image information alone is not sufficient to accurately recover 3 -- D shape . Our approach is based on the iterative deformation of a 3 -- D surface mesh to minimize an objective function . We show that combining anisotropic meshing with a non-quadratic approach to regularization enables us to obtain satisfactory reconstruction results using triangulations with few vertices . Structural or numerical constraints can then be added locally to the reconstruction process through a constrained optimization scheme . They improve the reconstruction results and enforce their consistency with a priori knowledge about object shape . The strong description and modeling properties of differential features make them useful tools that can be efficiently used as constraints for 3 -- D reconstruction .

Predicate-propose_to_incorporate.label: propose to incorporate
Predicate-propose_to_incorporate.description: To propose to incorporate means to suggest or recommend the integration of something (e.g. concepts, principles, rules) into a larger framework, system, or structure. This predicate indicates that the subject intends to bring together disparate elements to form a cohesive whole, often with the goal of creating a new entity or enhancing an existing one.

Predicate-to_incorporate.label: to incorporate
Predicate-to_incorporate.description: To incorporate refers to the act of integrating or merging one thing into another, often implying a sense of unity, coherence, and wholeness. This predicate connects the subject (the proposer) with an object that represents a concept, idea, or principle being brought together or assimilated.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: The predicate 'is based on' indicates that the subject's foundation or underlying principle is the object. It suggests a relationship where the subject relies heavily on, draws inspiration from, or has its core idea rooted in the object.

Predicate-to_minimize.label: to minimize
Predicate-to_minimize.description: To minimize connects the subject and object by indicating that the action or process described by the subject aims to reduce or decrease the magnitude of the object. This predicate suggests a goal-oriented relationship, where the subject strives to achieve a lower value or smaller quantity for the object.

Predicate-can_be_added_locally_to.label: can be added locally to
Predicate-can_be_added_locally_to.description: This predicate indicates that a specific element (the subject) has the ability to be incorporated into another entity (the object), typically in a manner that does not require significant changes or reorganization of the overall structure. The incorporation can occur at a local level, without affecting other parts of the system or process.

Predicate-improve.label: improve
Predicate-improve.description: To improve means to enhance or increase the quality, effectiveness, or efficiency of something. It implies a positive change in the subject's state or performance, often resulting from deliberate effort or action.

Predicate-improve_and_enforce_their_cons.label: improve and enforce their consistency with
Predicate-improve_and_enforce_their_cons.description: The predicate 'improve and enforce their consistency with' indicates a process of refining or standardizing the subject's understanding to align it with some existing knowledge, principle, or framework represented by the object. This connection enables the subject to better comprehend, apply, or make decisions based on the information provided by the object.

Predicate-make_them_useful_tools_that_ca.label: make them useful tools that can be efficiently used as constraints for
Predicate-make_them_useful_tools_that_ca.description: This predicate indicates a transformation of the subject into something that enables efficient use as constraints for achieving or accomplishing the object. It implies that the subject possesses certain properties, characteristics, or features that make it suitable and effective in serving as constraints to guide or inform the process described by the object.

Predicate-enables.label: enables
Predicate-enables.description: The predicate 'enables' indicates that the subject has the capacity or authority to make something possible, feasible, or effective. It implies a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject's action or state allows for or facilitates the occurrence of the described event or outcome.

Predicate-can_be_added.label: can be added
Predicate-can_be_added.description: The predicate 'can be added' indicates that something (typically an element, feature, or property) has the potential to be incorporated into or combined with another thing. It suggests a possibility of augmentation, extension, or enhancement.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is a specific instance or example of a more general category or concept represented by the object. The relationship between the subject and object is one of instantiation, where the subject is a particular manifestation or application of the broader concept denoted by the object.
